Cowboy_Crush:
{{Short description|American country music band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Cowboy Crush | image = | caption = | image_size = | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | genre = [[country music|Country]] | years_active = 2003—2009 | label = [[Asylum Records|Asylum]]-[[Curb Records|Curb]] | past_members = Trenna Barnes
Debbie Johnson
Darla Perlozzi
[[Becky Priest]]
Renaé Truex }} '''Cowboy Crush''' was an American [[country music]] band signed to [[Curb Records]]' Asylum/Curb division. The group is composed of Trenna Barnes ([[lead vocals]]), Debbie Johnson ([[bass guitar]], vocals), Becky Priest ([[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]], vocals), and Renaé Truex ([[fiddle]], [[mandolin]]). Until 2006, Darla Perlozzi ([[Drum kit|drums]]) was also a member of the group. Perlozzi co-wrote [[Big & Rich]]'s 2007 single "Loud". All five founding members of Cowboy Crush had previously worked throughout [[Nashville, Tennessee]] before meeting at [[Belmont University]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20050716075122/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/cowboy_crush/bio.jhtml CMT.com : Cowboy Crush : Biography] They held their first practice together in a garage on March 18, 2003. Cowboy Crush is also known for its high-energy concerts and backstage antics.[http://www.countrymusicfestival.com/ccrushinfo.htm Cowboy Crush] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707210902/http://www.countrymusicfestival.com/ccrushinfo.htm |date=2007-07-07 }} The group's debut single, "Nobody Ever Died of a Broken Heart", was previously recorded by [[Trick Pony]]. Cowboy Crush's debut album was released to digital retailers on July 14, 2009. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:16em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Cowboy Crush'' | * Release date: July 14, 2009 * Label: [[Curb Records]] |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:20em;"| Single ! colspan="1"| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="65"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]] |- | rowspan="2"| 2005 ! scope="row"| "Nobody Ever Died of a Broken Heart" | 56 |- ! scope="row"| "He's Coming Home" | — |- | 2006 ! scope="row"| "Hillbilly Nation"{{cite web | url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/hillbilly-nation-single/129511827 | title='Hillbilly Nation' - Single | publisher=iTunes | accessdate=June 26, 2023}} | — |- | rowspan="2"| 2007 ! scope="row"| "Some Men Don't Cheat" | — |- ! scope="row"| "Miss Difficult" | — |- | rowspan="2"| 2009 ! scope="row"| "Tougher Than a Man" | — |- ! scope="row"| "Hillbilly Soldier" | — |- | colspan="4" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" !
